target_text: "We aim for clean code. This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines. We also aim for sustainability of the design. This means the software design is able to cope with new requirements easily moving forward."

Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a master’s in Geography, I approach spatial-economic questions through a pragmatic lens, prioritizing actionable insights for decision-making. My research interest in Economics steers me toward regional development, market accessibility, and place-based policy evaluation, often privileging quantitative, GIS-enabled evidence. I recognize my epistemological assumptions—positivist-leaning and optimization-oriented—which may undervalue lived experience and alternative ontologies. The way questions are framed and how users respond guide my sampling, coding, and model choices, potentially amplifying dominant stakeholder voices. By foregrounding reflexivity and triangulation, I seek to balance efficiency with equity and contextual nuance in interpreting results.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing bachelor’s-level study in statistics, I bring computational problem-solving and data-driven habits to economic inquiry. My research goal is to produce reproducible, statistically rigorous analyses that inform practical economic decisions. I recognize that my cultural background, personal experiences, and a developer’s efficiency mindset can bias variable selection, model choice, and preference for quantifiable outcomes. To mitigate this, I triangulate methods, document assumptions, and invite critique. The question and user responses further shape my framing, operationalization, and interpretation, prompting reflexive checks that align my methods with the study’s context and stakeholders’ perspectives.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a master’s-level inquiry, bringing a computational mindset to anthropological questions. Guided by anthropology (QS) and research interests in economics (NSF), I aim to examine how digital infrastructures mediate economic behavior and inequality. My practice is shaped by ethical and societal assumptions—valuing fairness, privacy, open access, and sometimes technological solutionism—which I interrogate through reflexivity. The framing of the Question and the User’s Response directs my attention to certain categories and language, potentially privileging measurable patterns over lived meanings. Consequently, my interpretations may foreground systems, incentives, and data, while I strive to center participant voices and cultural context.

Role_init_codebook.role: PhD Qualitative Software Engineering Researcher (QS: CS/IS; NSF: Software Engineering/HCC; Bias: standards- and maintainability-centric)

codebook.justification: As a PhD qualitative SE researcher (QS: CS/IS; NSF: SE), I read [clean code] as a value-laden quality norm. My standards-centric bias equates 'clean' with readability, cohesion, and low coupling.

From a lifecycle-centric SE lens, [maintainable code] prioritizes evolvability over near-term throughput. My maintainability-first bias invokes subjective proxies (code smells, indices) rather than definitive ground truth.
I interpret [confirms to well established guidelines] as normative alignment with community standards. Bias: I privilege linters and style guides as quality signals despite context-dependence.

As design-methods oriented, [sustainability of the design] encodes future-proofing. My HCC/SE stance reads [cope with new requirements easily] as adaptability, trading simplicity (YAGNI) for resilience.

Role_init_codebook.role: PhD-level Reflective Qualitative Software Engineering Researcher (QS: Computer Science; NSF: Software & Hardware Systems)

codebook.justification: As a PhD-level reflective SE scholar (QS: CS; NSF: SE), I treat 'clean' as a negotiated norm. The aspiration is explicit in [We aim for clean code.], signaling value-laden quality intent.

My bias favors guideline-driven quality heuristics (style guides, SOLID), linking standards to maintainability. This coupling is asserted via [maintainable code] aligned to [well established guidelines].
With an NSF interest in sustainable software systems, I elevate long-term viability as a core criterion. That intent is declared in [We also aim for sustainability of the design.].
Doctoral training inclines me to see evolvability as context-contingent, not binary. Adaptivity is foregrounded in [able to cope with new requirements], highlighting future-oriented design judgment.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Software Engineering Researcher (PhD; QS: Computer Science; NSF: Software Engineering; Biases: maintainability-first, standards-oriented, long-termism)

codebook.justification: From a software engineering research lens, I read [maintainable code] and [clean code] as prioritizing long-term quality over delivery speed. My maintainability-first bias amplifies this theme.
The phrase [confirms to well established guidelines] frames normative standard adherence in coding practice. As a standards-oriented PhD researcher, I code this as intentional conformance.
The stated goal [sustainability of the design] centers lifecycle stewardship and architectural longevity. My long-termism bias foregrounds durability over short-term optimization.
Declaring the design [able to cope with new requirements easily] indicates adaptability and extensibility intent. This aligns with my SE focus on evolvability and forward-compatibility.

Agreed.definition: The statement defines clean code as both maintainable and compliant with standards: [This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines.].
There is an explicit long-term design goal: [We also aim for sustainability of the design.], indicating lifecycle durability and architectural longevity.
Sustainability is operationalized as evolvability: [This means the software design is able to cope with new requirements easily moving forward.].

Disagreed.definition: Diverges by asserting a trade-off/priority (e.g., over delivery speed) that the text does not make; the text simply commits to [This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines.].

Diverges by importing extra qualities (e.g., readability, low coupling) not stated in the provided definition; the text constrains 'clean' to [This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines.].
Frames 'clean code' as a negotiated ideal rather than the explicit commitment stated in [We aim for clean code.], adding abstraction beyond the text’s concrete definition.

disagree_explain:
Disagreements concern three codes: Maintainability priority—roles inferred a trade-off (e.g., over speed) not in the text, which only commits to [This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines.]. Clean code ethos—roles imported extra qualities (readability, low coupling) beyond that definition. Clean code ideal—roles reframed [We aim for clean code.] as a negotiated ideal, adding abstraction beyond the text’s concrete meaning.
**Click on the option under Disagreed Items on the left to start the discussion**

Closing.definition: Use this disagreement code when a claim asserts that maintainability is prioritized over other concerns. The source text only commits to clean, maintainable code and design sustainability, without ranking or trade-offs. Flag introduced hierarchies or priorities not explicitly stated by the text.

Retain the code because the source text defines 'clean code' narrowly as maintainable code conforming to well‑established guidelines and treats sustainability as a separate aim. The code helps flag scope creep, preserving annotation precision and consistency with the stated definitions.

The source makes an explicit commitment—“We aim for clean code”—and immediately defines it operationally. Labeling it an “ideal” introduces abstraction not in the text and reduces precision. Unretain to keep annotations aligned with concrete, text-grounded commitments.

Codebook.definition: The statement defines clean code as both maintainable and compliant with standards: [This mean maintainable code that confirms to well established guidelines.].
There is an explicit long-term design goal: [We also aim for sustainability of the design.], indicating lifecycle durability and architectural longevity.
Sustainability is operationalized as evolvability: [This means the software design is able to cope with new requirements easily moving forward.].
